title: Local Server Fundamentals
overview: Understanding how servers work on your local machine, the localhost concept, and basic HTTP server setup. You'll learn to run a simple web server and access it from your local network.
objectives: Understand localhost, loopback interface (127.0.0.1), and how servers listen on ports
Create and run a basic Node.js HTTP server
Access your local server from other devices on your LAN
Identify your local IP address and understand private IP ranges

sections.title: Understanding Localhost and Network Interfaces
sections.content:
# Understanding Localhost

When you run a server on your computer, it typically listens on a **network interface**. The most common is:

- **localhost (127.0.0.1)**: The loopback interface, only accessible from your own machine
- **0.0.0.0**: All network interfaces, making your server accessible on your LAN
- **Your LAN IP (e.g., 192.168.1.x)**: Your private IP address on your local network

## How Servers Listen

A server "listens" on a **port** (like 3000, 8080, or 80). Think of ports as different doors into your computer:

```
http://localhost:3000 → Your machine, port 3000
http://192.168.1.100:3000 → Same server, but accessible from LAN
```

## Private IP Ranges

These IP ranges are reserved for private networks (not routable on the internet):
- **10.0.0.0 – 10.255.255.255**
- **172.16.0.0 – 172.31.255.255**
- **192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255**

Your router assigns you one of these IPs via DHCP.

miniProject.title: LAN-Accessible Web Server
miniProject.description: Create a personal dashboard server that displays system information and is accessible from any device on your local network.
steps: Create a new Node.js project with `npm init -y`
Build an HTTP server that listens on 0.0.0.0:3000
Serve an HTML page showing: server hostname, current time, request count
Find your local IP address using ipconfig/ifconfig
Access your server from another device on your network (phone, tablet, another computer)
Add a simple API endpoint `/api/info` that returns JSON with server stats
deliverables: A running Node.js server accessible via LAN
HTML dashboard showing live server information
Documentation of your local IP and how you accessed it from another device
rubric: Accessible via localhost and LAN IP (3 pts)
API endpoint returns valid JSON (2 pts)

questions.question: What does 127.0.0.1 refer to?
questions.explanation: 127.0.0.1 is the loopback address, allowing your computer to talk to itself. It's never exposed to the network.

questions.question: Which IP address range is reserved for private networks?
questions.explanation: 192.168.x.x is one of the three private IP ranges defined in RFC 1918. The others are 10.x.x.x and 172.16.x.x-172.31.x.x.

questions.question: What does listening on 0.0.0.0 mean?
options: The server only accepts connections from localhost
The server listens on all available network interfaces
The server only accepts connections from the internet
questions.correctAnswer: The server listens on all available network interfaces
questions.explanation: 0.0.0.0 is a meta-address that tells the server to bind to all network interfaces (localhost, LAN, etc.).

questions.question: Which of the following are true about ports? (Select all that apply)
options: You can run multiple servers on the same port simultaneously
Port 80 is the default for HTTP
correctAnswer: Port 80 is the default for HTTP
questions.explanation: Ports 0-1023 are well-known/system ports. HTTP uses 80, HTTPS uses 443. Ports range from 0-65535. Only one process can bind to a port at a time.

questions.question: How can you find your local IP address on Windows?
questions.explanation: ipconfig displays network configuration on Windows. On Linux/macOS, you'd use ifconfig or 'ip addr show'.

questions.question: Explain the difference between localhost and 0.0.0.0 when starting a server.
questions.correctAnswer: localhost (127.0.0.1) only allows connections from the same machine, while 0.0.0.0 binds to all network interfaces, making the server accessible from other devices on the network.
questions.explanation: This is a key concept: localhost is loopback-only, while 0.0.0.0 opens your server to LAN access. For production, you'd typically use a specific interface or add firewall rules.

setupSteps: Install Node.js LTS from nodejs.org (includes npm)
Create a project directory: mkdir my-server && cd my-server
Create server.js with the basic HTTP server code
commands: netstat -an | findstr :3000  # Windows: check if port is in use
lsof -i :3000   # macOS/Linux: check if port is in use

troubleshooting.issue: Error: listen EADDRINUSE - Port already in use
troubleshooting.solution: Another process is using that port. Change the port number in your code, or find and kill the process using that port (netstat on Windows, lsof on macOS/Linux).

troubleshooting.issue: Cannot access server from another device on LAN
troubleshooting.solution: 1) Check your firewall allows incoming connections on that port. 2) Ensure you're using 0.0.0.0, not localhost. 3) Verify both devices are on the same network. 4) Use your LAN IP (192.168.x.x), not localhost.
The 'http' module is built into Node.js. This error usually means Node.js isn't installed properly. Reinstall Node.js from nodejs.org.
